Plots¶

This module contains code for making plots. This code is used mainly for the plots in cluster.Viewer. So, it isn’t really intended to be used, but feel free to of course.

plots.autocorr(*args, **kwargs)¶

Plots the autocorrelation of times.

plots.color_array(clusters, color_dict)¶

Returns a 1D array with the color for each data point

plots.correlogram(t1, t2=None, bin_width=0.001, limit=0.02, auto=False)¶

Return crosscorrelogram of two spike trains.

Essentially, this algorithm subtracts each spike time in t1 from all of t2 and bins the results with numpy.histogram, though several tweaks were made for efficiency.

Arguments

t1 : first spiketrain, raw spike times in seconds. t2 : second spiketrain, raw spike times in seconds. bin_width : width of each bar in histogram in sec limit : positive and negative extent of histogram, in seconds auto : if True, then returns autocorrelogram of t1 and in

this case t2 can be None.
Returns

(count, bins) : a tuple containing the bin edges (in seconds) and the count of spikes in each bin.

bins is relative to t1. That is, if t1 leads t2, then count will peak in a positive time bin.

plots.crosscorr(*args, **kwargs)¶

Plots the cross-correlation of t1 and t2.

plots.feature_trace(*args, **kwargs)¶

Plot feature values over time.

Generate multiple axes on a figure, given the number of desired plots and columns.

plots.generate_crosscorr_axes(n_rows, n_cols, **kwargs)¶

Return a dict of indices and axes for the figure used in cross-correlations.

plots.get_colors(K, colormap=<matplotlib.colors.LinearSegmentedColormap object at 0x103ec5a10>)¶

Method for setting the colors used when plotting clusters.

plots.limit_data(data, max_limit)¶

Returns data points limited in number by max_limit

plots.passed_or_new_ax(func)¶

This is a decorator for the plots in this module. Most plots can be passed an existing axis to plot on. If it isn’t passed an axis, then a new figure and new axis should be generated and passed to the plot. This decorator ensures this happens.

plots.scatter(*args, **kwargs)¶

Generates a scatter plot. The number of points is reduced by the value of trim, so if you are plotting a bunch of points, it won’t show them all. Set trim=0.5 to plot half the points, for example.

Arguments

x, y:
array-like, must be the same length, data values to plot
ax:
matplotlib axes
trim:
float between 0 and 1, inclusive, trims data points
colors:
colors of the data points, can be an array of the same length as x and y
plots.scatter3D(x, y, z, ax=None, trim=1, colors='k')¶

Generates a scatter plot in 3D. The number of points is reduced by the value of trim, so if you are plotting a bunch of points, it won’t show them all. Set trim=0.5 to plot half the points, for example.

plots.spikes(*args, **kwargs)¶

Plots the spike waveforms assuming the data is from a tetrode.

Arguments
data:
Array of spike waveforms
ax:
Matplotlib axis
color:
Color of the waveforms
limit:
Number of waveforms to plot
plots.timestamps(*args, **kwargs)¶

Plot time stamps, randomly scattered along the y-axis.

plots.trim_data(*args, **kwargs)¶

Returns a smaller number of data points, reduced by the value of trim. Useful for plotting fewer points for speed purposes.

Arguments

Any number of position arguments. They should all be numpy arrays of the same dimension.

Keywords trim : float between 0 and 1, inclusive.

This is the factor the data points are trimmed by.
